description:
Citrobacter freundii is a Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that belongs to the Enterobacteriaceae family. It is a facultative anaerobe, meaning it can grow in the presence or absence of oxygen. Citrobacter freundii is commonly found in the environment, including soil, water, and the gastrointestinal tract of humans and animals.

This species is known for its ability to ferment a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, lactose, and sucrose, and can produce gas during the fermentation process. Citrobacter freundii is also capable of utilizing a wide range of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources, which contributes to its adaptability and distribution in various environmental niches.

Citrobacter freundii is considered an opportunistic pathogen, as it can cause infections in immunocompromised individuals or those with underlying medical conditions. It has been associated with various types of infections, including urinary tract infections, septicemia, pneumonia, and meningitis. The pathogenicity of Citrobacter freundii is attributed to its ability to produce virulence factors, such as adhesins, toxins, and enzymes, which can facilitate invasion and colonization of host tissues.

Due to its versatile metabolic capabilities and potential for causing infections, Citrobacter freundii is an important species in both environmental and clinical microbiology, and its study can provide insights into the ecology and pathogenesis of this opportunistic microorganism.
